newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan enters the age of multichannel satellite TV.
newsitem.headline: Japan enters the age of multichannel satellite TV.

text.p: PerfecTV, set to start Japan's first multi-channel digital satellite broadcasting service, said on Monday it hopes to acquire one million subscribers by next summer, when the entry of rivals will intensify competition.
"Our strategy is to acquire as many subscribers as possible by the time our two rivals launch their services next summer," PerfecTV president Hiroto Kasahara told a news conference.

PerfecTV, owned by a consortium headed by trading company Itochu Corp, will launch a 57-channel paid service on Tuesday beamed directly via the JCSAT-3 communications satellite. The number of channels will be raised to 70 by December and to 110 next year.
The basic monthly fee is set at 2,900 yen ($26).

The company will be followed by a 150-channel service called J-SkyB, to be launched by Australian media tycoon Rupert Murdoch's News Corp and Japan's Softbank Corp, and a 100-channel service by DirecTV, planned by a unit of Hughes Electronics Corp of the United States.
Compression of data achieved with digital technology allows for far more information to be broadcast than with conventional analog systems.
Kasahara said 20,000 individual subscribers have already signed up for PerfecTV.
"Because there are so many inquiries on the new service, we haven't been able to cope appropriately," he said.
Kasahara said there was a possibility the company would go ahead with a proposed tie-up with J-SkyB which would give its viewers access to J-SkyB programmes through a single receiver and dish.
"I have always said it would be a lot more convenient to Japanese viewers if the three service providers use a single decoder and dish," he said.
PerfecTV may start selling decoders which also allow access to J-SkyB next year, he said. A dish and decoder together currently cost about 50,000 yen ($450).
The launching of digital satellite broadcasting in Japan is expected to spawn a host of related products and create a huge sales opportunity for the nation's top electronics manufacturers
Analysts expect the market for dishes and decoders alone to exceed 70 billion yen ($630 million) within the next few years.

Some analysts say demand will increase further after PerfecTV starts data transmission services using communications satellites, which would allow its subscribers fast access to computer data through their decoders.
PerfecTV has said it plans to start satellite data transmission services within a few years. ($1=111 yen)
